Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Development of Earth-Abundant Mixed-Metal Sulfide Nanoparticles for use in Solar Energy Conversion
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the CAREER research and education project of Prof. Katherine Plass of Franklin & Marshall College. Prof. Plass and her undergraduate researchers will develop new syntheses of inexpensive nanoparticles designed to act as light-absorbers in photovoltaics. Specifically, the Plass group will create solid solutions consisting of highly abundant elements. This will afford nanoparticles with band gaps tunable from the near-infrared to the ultraviolet region, thereby enabling construction of low-cost nanoparticle-based multijunction photovoltaics. To create these compounds, the team will design precursors that induce cations with different sizes and affinities to react to form sulfides at similar rates. Surface chemistry and film formation will be studied to create chemically stable nanoparticle films that have the necessary high conductivities to efficiently collect photogenerated charges. Finally, photovoltaic devices will be constructed using these nanoparticles made from earth-abundant elements.

Undergraduate students will carry out the research, author publications, and present results at national meetings, positioning them well for entry into graduate school. The undergraduate researchers performing this work represent the newest generation of well-trained scientists interested in using chemistry to develop renewable energy. Alternative energy research in general and this work in particular will be incorporated into undergraduate classes and outreach activities with the North Museum of Natural History & Science aimed at the general public and local grade school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Copper sulfide nanoparticles have many properties that make them promising for solar energy conversion—they strongly absorb solar energy and consist of highly abundant elements—but they suffer from a high mobility of copper ions that results in instability of optical properties and atomic arrangements. We were able to address these issues through incorporation of other species to produce mixed-metal sulfides. In the process we developed widely applicable new synthesis methods. Specifically, we have identified systems in which the arrangement of atoms in copper sulfide (by variation of solvent ratios) and in copper iron sulfides (by alteration of element ratios under the right conditions) can be systematically altered to create a variety of different forms with different structures, different levels of stability with respect to changing arrangement, and tunable optical properties. We then employed these different forms as scaffolds to incorporate additional metals, creating a general strategy of production of complex mixed-metal sulfide nanoparticles. Furthermore, we have identified ways to treat the surfaces of these particles to make them more stable, thereby retaining the optical properties useful for solar energy conversion.

Eighteen undergraduate student researchers have been involved in this project over the life of the grant, working closely with faculty and their peers. These transformative undergraduate research experiences deepen the knowledge gained from courses by engaging students in the creative scientific process and train students to become leaders in their scientific fields. The vast majority of students involved demonstrated how much they valued these experiences by committing to an entire academic year of research or more. Of the 15 students who have graduated, three are pursuing medical training, one is involved in STEM education, and eight are in chemistry graduate school.
